news.title: Seven Things to Tell Your Crypto-Curious Relatives at Thanksgiving
news.content: It's a wild time for crypto. Your relatives may have questions during Thanksgiving. Here are some helpful talking points to get you through.

news.title: Bitcoin and Dogecoin Rebound as Ethereum Hits 5-Month High Price
news.content: Bitcoin, Ethereum, and even Dogecoin are experiencing a surge in prices ahead of Thanksgiving after dipping at the start of the week.

news.title: 2025 Stock Playbook: Tap Into AI's $1 Trillion Potential, US Growth Opportunities - Apple  ( NASDAQ:AAPL ) , Amazon.com  ( NASDAQ:AMZN )
news.content: Wall Street eyes 2025 with confidence as JPMorgan declares the U.S. will remain the global growth leader. While Europe wrestles with structural woes, the emerging markets face headwinds from high interest rates and a strong dollar.

news.title: Musk, Ramaswamy to discuss DOGE with GOP leaders on Capitol Hill Dec. 5
news.content: Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy will visit Capitol Hill to discuss government reform with Republican congressional leaders Dec. 5, House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., announced Wednesday.

news.title: Elon Musk's xAI goes after OpenAI
news.content: Elon Musk’s xAI goes after OpenAI The EconomistThe Economist/>Skip to contentMenuWeekly editionThe world in briefSearchLog inOpinionLeadersLetters to the editorBy InvitationCurrent topicsWar in the Middle EastWar in UkraineThe World Ahead 2025Climate changeGeopoliticsThe world economyArtificial intelligenceCurrent topicsWar in the Middle EastWar in UkraineThe World Ahead 2025Climate changeGeopoliticsThe world economyArtificial intelligenceWorldThe world this weekChinaUnited StatesEuropeBritainMiddle East & AfricaAsiaThe AmericasInternationalA-Z of international relationsA-Z of military termsA-Z of US politicsUS presidential trackerIn depthScience & technologyBriefingGraphic detailThe Economist explainsSpecial reportsTechnology QuarterlyEssaySchools briefBusiness & economicsFinance & economicsBusinessBig Mac indexA-Z of economicsEconomic & financial indicatorsCulture & society1843 magazineCultureObituaryThe Economist readsChristmas SpecialsMorePodcastsNewslettersVideoThe Economist appSecureDropSubscriber eventsEconomist Education coursesEconomist EnterpriseMy EconomistSaved storiesLog outSaved storiesAccountLog outSearchSearchBusiness | Tycoons in a knife fight Elon Musk’s xAI goes after OpenAI The fight is turning nasty Eyes on the competitionPhotograph: Reuters Nov 27th 2024|SAN FRANCISCO ShareAn underappreciated force behind great technological change is intense—and petty—rivalry. In the “war of the currents” in the late 19th century, Thomas Edison electrocuted stray animals to discredit Nikola Tesla. A century later Steve Jobs traded insults with Bill Gates during a battle between Apple and Microsoft. Even “Silicon Valley,” a satirical HBO series, starts with a feud—and the priceless quip: “These are billionaires, Richard. Humiliating each other is worth more to them than we will make in a lifetime.”Explore moreElon MuskArtificial intelligenceSam AltmanOpenAITechnologyThis article appeared in the Business section of the print edition under the headline “Tycoons in a knife fight ”Business November 30th 2024Will the trouble ever end for Volkswagen and its rivals?
